title: 'Turn the tide on plastic' urges UN, as microplastics in the seas now ...
body: "Plastic pollution is surfing onto Indonesian beaches, settling onto the ocean floor at the North Pole, and rising through the food chain onto our dinner tables," Erik Solheim, the Executive Director of UNEP, said in a news release announcing the campaign. "We've stood by too long as the problem has gotten worse.
readable_content: - UN Website (2023-12-08): The United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) has launched a campaign urging everyone to eliminate the use of microplastics and curb the excessive use of single-use plastics to protect the world's oceans from irreversible damage. The campaign, Clean Seas, aims to get countries and businesses to take ambitious measures such as banning or taxing single-use plastic bags and reducing disposable plastic items. The agency has also emphasized the importance of individual actions, such as using reusable shopping bags and water bottles, in reducing plastic pollution. Additionally, supply chains are encouraged to use recovered ocean plastic in products. Major announcements related to this issue are expected at upcoming UN conferences. The President of the UN General Assembly has also urged for ambitious pledges to reduce single-use plastic to protect the oceans.
summary:
The post from the UN website promotes the importance of eliminating the use of microplastics and single-use plastics to protect the world's oceans. It emphasizes the need for ambitious measures by countries and businesses, as well as individual actions, to reduce plastic pollution. The initiative is backed by global leaders and aims to address this critical environmental issue.
